sen.j: 大参事（だいさんじ）は、明治時代初期の府藩県三治制の時期に置かれた、地方官の長官に次ぐ官職。
sen.e: Daisanji was a government post next to a chief of chihokan (a local official) placed during the time of fu-han-ken sanchisei (fu-han-ken tripartite governance system) in the early Meiji period.

sen.j: 明治2年、版籍奉還後の官制改正で、都道府県知事（知府事・知藩事・知県事）の下に正・権の大参事を置くと定められた（県には権官はなし）。
sen.e: In 1869, it was decided that Sei Daisanji (formal Daisanji) and Gon Daisanji (temporary Daisanji) should have been placed under prefectural governors (Chifuji [prefectural governor], Chihanji [domain governor], Chikenji [prefectural governor]) by the reform of the governmental regulations after the return of lands and people to the emperor. (There was no gonkan [supernumerary position] in prefectures.)

sen.j: 諸藩の正・権大参事は、公議所を兼任することとされ、公議所が廃止された後は、いずれか1名が集議院の議員となった。
sen.e: Sei and Gon Daisanji in domains must concurrently have been a member of Kogisho (the lower house) but after the Kogisho had been abolished, either of them became a councilor of Shugiin (whose name was changed from Kogisho).
